body.p: Besides other Among the things arising out of this war, which sweeps every thing into and swept swelled into its vast and unprecedented proportions scales scale making all the old standards unapplicable unsuitable & petty, are the present great Military Hospitals. Great they are already, & rapidly growing greater w there & in with most of the cities of the middle states. The newspaper reader through the Union & northern states, sees frequent allusions to them, but has , probably little true idea of them. Here in Washington, theythey already contain a population greater in itself than the whole of the Washington of ten years ago. Within sight of the Capitol, to‑day are forty of these hospitals or camps, for the army sick & wounded. I Sometimes the number of these inmates of these comprises over from fifty to eighty thousand men. The buildings are peculiar Often from Looking from an eminence, and study; the topography in my rambles I use them as landmarks.
Every thing in our country, radiating here in Washington or radiating from it, these days, every thing is on such a vast & unprecedented scale as to astound one.

Every thing connected with this tremendous war, and with our country any how America, these days, is on such a vast and unprecedented scale,—among the as to astound one. one has to give up all the old standards, as tame & too petty. Among the rest, our presentgreat mMilitary Hospitals. (great, yet week growing) Within sight here in and around Washington, and around it, from any eminence, you can count twenty or thirty of them. such huge Hospitals. Through the rich June verdure of the trees, see the white walls of that white bunch of white buildings off on the high grounds in the suburban outskirts; then another cluster half a mile
12 A
from to the left of the first, and another a mile in to the right, and another a mile beyond, and still another between us and the first,. and in And indeed we one can hardly look in any direction but these Hospitals are dotting the beautiful landscape of this District. Washington's environs.

Far off on the brow of a hill see that town, as you might suppose; yes but, a town of the wounded & sick & dying. wounds, sickness & death. It is the Finley Hospital, north east of the city,on Kendall green ( as it used to be called.) But a N Not far off from it is the Campbell Hospital. Both are large establishments. I have known these two establishments hospitals alone to have nearly twenty-five hundred inmates.
body.note: (get list of hospitals, correct at date)
